what: What if my data has more categories than the number of colors offered?
title: Frequently Asked Questions about ggsci
text: Although recommended encode many categories different colors, practice, one can still create ‚Äúadaptive‚Äù color palette based existing discrete color palettes ggsci. See blog post detailed guide creating adaptive ggplot2 color scales color interpolation.

what: Use a color scale consistently for multiple plots in a document
title: Frequently Asked Questions about ggsci
text: apply color scale plots document avoid repetition, simple solution setting two global options ggplot2.discrete.colour ggplot2.discrete.fill. example:
code: library("ggplot2")  p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, colour = factor(cyl), fill = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point() +   geom_smooth(method = "lm") +   theme_bw()  p  # Set global options options(   ggplot2.discrete.colour = ggsci::scale_colour_d3,   ggplot2.discrete.fill = ggsci::scale_fill_d3 )  p  # Restore original options after use options(   ggplot2.discrete.colour = NULL,   ggplot2.discrete.fill = NULL )  p

what: Customize color ordering in a palette
title: Frequently Asked Questions about ggsci
text: can customize color selection ordering discrete color palette ggsci using following function returns custom color scale function. method flexible encourages code reuse. Use scale_color_custom() example:
code: #' Define a custom color scale #' #' @param pal Name of the color palette, as part of the #'   original palette function name. #' @param palette Palette type, as defined in the #'   original palette function (optional). #' @param n Number of (first) colors to fetch from the original palette. #' @param order A vector of color index (optional). #' @param alpha Transparency level. #' #' @return A custom color scale function. scale_color_custom <- function(pal, palette, n, order, alpha = 1) {   pal <- getFromNamespace(paste0("pal_", pal), "ggsci")    colors <- if (missing(palette)) {     pal(alpha = alpha)(n)   } else {     pal(palette = palette, alpha = alpha)(n)   }    if (length(order) > length(colors)) {     stop("The length of order exceeds the number of colors.", call. = FALSE)   }   colors <- if (!missing(order)) colors[order]    ggplot2::scale_color_manual(values = colors) } library(ggplot2) library(ggsci)  set.seed(42) df <- data.frame(   x = rnorm(100),   y = rnorm(100),   group = factor(sample(1:5, 100, replace = TRUE)) )  p <- ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y, color = group)) +   geom_point(size = 3) +   theme_minimal()  p + scale_color_custom("d3", palette = "category20", n = 20, order = c(14, 11, 13, 12, 15))

title: Scientific Journal and Sci-Fi Themed Color Palettes for ggplot2
text: eyes finally opened understood nature. learned time love . ‚Äî Claude Monet ggsci offers collection high-quality color palettes inspired colors used scientific journals, data visualization libraries, science fiction movies, TV shows. color palettes ggsci available ggplot2 scales. color palettes, corresponding scales named : scale_color_palname() scale_fill_palname() also provided aliases, scale_colour_palname() scale_color_palname(). available color palettes summarized table .

title: Scientific Journal and Sci-Fi Themed Color Palettes for ggplot2
text: use scatterplots smooth curves, bar plots demonstrate discrete color palettes ggsci.
code: library("ggsci") library("ggplot2") library("gridExtra")  data("diamonds")  p1 <- ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat >= 2.2),   aes(x = table, y = price, colour = cut) ) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +   geom_smooth(method = "loess", alpha = 0.05, linewidth = 1, span = 1) +   theme_bw()  p2 <- ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat > 2.2 & depth > 55 & depth < 70),   aes(x = depth, fill = cut) ) +   geom_histogram(colour = "black", binwidth = 1, position = "dodge") +   theme_bw()

text: use correlation matrix visualization (special type heatmap) demonstrate continuous color palettes ggsci.
code: library("reshape2")  data("mtcars") cor <- cor(unname(cbind(mtcars, mtcars, mtcars, mtcars))) cor_melt <- melt(cor)  p3 <- ggplot(   cor_melt,   aes(x = Var1, y = Var2, fill = value) ) +   geom_tile(colour = "black", linewidth = 0.3) +   theme_void() +   theme(     axis.title.x = element_blank(),     axis.title.y = element_blank()   )

title: Scientific Journal and Sci-Fi Themed Color Palettes for ggplot2
text: Material Design color palettes Material Design color system. generate random matrix first: Plot matrix 19 material design color palettes:  figure , can see even though identical matrix visualized plots, palettes preferrable others eyes sensitive changes saturation levels.
code: library("reshape2")  set.seed(42) k <- 9 x <- diag(k) x[upper.tri(x)] <- runif(sum(1:(k - 1)), 0, 1) x_melt <- melt(x)  p4 <- ggplot(x_melt, aes(x = Var1, y = Var2, fill = value)) +   geom_tile(colour = "black", linewidth = 0.3) +   scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0, 0)) +   scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0, 0)) +   theme_bw() +   theme(     legend.position = "none", plot.background = element_blank(),     axis.line = element_blank(), axis.ticks = element_blank(),     axis.text.x = element_blank(), axis.text.y = element_blank(),     axis.title.x = element_blank(), axis.title.y = element_blank(),     panel.background = element_blank(), panel.border = element_blank(),     panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank()   ) grid.arrange(   p4 + scale_fill_material("red"), p4 + scale_fill_material("pink"),   p4 + scale_fill_material("purple"), p4 + scale_fill_material("deep-purple"),   p4 + scale_fill_material("indigo"), p4 + scale_fill_material("blue"),   p4 + scale_fill_material("light-blue"), p4 + scale_fill_material("cyan"),   p4 + scale_fill_material("teal"), p4 + scale_fill_material("green"),   p4 + scale_fill_material("light-green"), p4 + scale_fill_material("lime"),   p4 + scale_fill_material("yellow"), p4 + scale_fill_material("amber"),   p4 + scale_fill_material("orange"), p4 + scale_fill_material("deep-orange"),   p4 + scale_fill_material("brown"), p4 + scale_fill_material("grey"),   p4 + scale_fill_material("blue-grey"),   ncol = 6 )

code: library("ggplot2") data("diamonds")  ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat >= 2.2),   aes(x = table, y = price, colour = cut) ) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +   geom_smooth(method = "loess", alpha = 0.1, size = 1, span = 1) +   theme_bw() + scale_color_aaas() #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ‚Ñπ Please use `linewidth` instead. #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'   ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat > 2.2 & depth > 55 & depth < 70),   aes(x = depth, fill = cut) ) +   geom_histogram(colour = "black", binwidth = 1, position = "dodge") +   theme_bw() + scale_fill_aaas()

code: library("ggplot2") data("diamonds")  p1 <- ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat >= 2.2),   aes(x = table, y = price, colour = cut) ) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +   geom_smooth(method = "loess", alpha = 0.1, size = 1, span = 1) +   theme_bw()  p2 <- ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat > 2.2 & depth > 55 & depth < 70),   aes(x = depth, fill = cut) ) +   geom_histogram(colour = "black", binwidth = 1, position = "dodge") +   theme_bw()  p1 + scale_color_d3() #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_d3()   p1 + scale_color_d3(palette = "category20") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_d3(palette = "category20")   p1 + scale_color_d3(palette = "category20b") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_d3(palette = "category20b")   p1 + scale_color_d3(palette = "category20c") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_d3(palette = "category20c")

code: library("ggplot2") data("diamonds")  p1 <- ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat >= 2.2),   aes(x = table, y = price, colour = cut) ) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +   geom_smooth(method = "loess", alpha = 0.1, size = 1, span = 1) +   theme_bw()  p2 <- ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat > 2.2 & depth > 55 & depth < 70),   aes(x = depth, fill = cut) ) +   geom_histogram(colour = "black", binwidth = 1, position = "dodge") +   theme_bw()  p1 + scale_color_flatui() #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_flatui()   p1 + scale_color_flatui(palette = "default") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_flatui(palette = "default")   p1 + scale_color_flatui(palette = "flattastic") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_flatui(palette = "flattastic")   p1 + scale_color_flatui(palette = "aussie") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_flatui(palette = "aussie")

title: Material Design Color Palettes ‚Äî scale_color_material
code: library("ggplot2") library("reshape2") data("mtcars")  cor <- abs(cor(mtcars)) cor_melt <- melt(cor)  ggplot(   cor_melt,   aes(x = Var1, y = Var2, fill = value) ) +   geom_tile(colour = "black", size = 0.3) +   theme_bw() + scale_fill_material("blue-grey")

title: NEJM Color Scales ‚Äî scale_color_nejm
code: library("ggplot2") data("diamonds")  ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat >= 2.2),   aes(x = table, y = price, colour = cut) ) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +   geom_smooth(method = "loess", alpha = 0.1, size = 1, span = 1) +   theme_bw() + scale_color_nejm() #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'   ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat > 2.2 & depth > 55 & depth < 70),   aes(x = depth, fill = cut) ) +   geom_histogram(colour = "black", binwidth = 1, position = "dodge") +   theme_bw() + scale_fill_nejm()

code: library("ggplot2") data("diamonds")  ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat >= 2.2),   aes(x = table, y = price, colour = cut) ) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +   geom_smooth(method = "loess", alpha = 0.1, size = 1, span = 1) +   theme_dark() + theme(     panel.background = element_rect(fill = "#2D2D2D"),     legend.key = element_rect(fill = "#2D2D2D")   ) +   scale_color_tron() #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'   ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat > 2.2 & depth > 55 & depth < 70),   aes(x = depth, fill = cut) ) +   geom_histogram(colour = "black", binwidth = 1, position = "dodge") +   theme_dark() + theme(     panel.background = element_rect(fill = "#2D2D2D")   ) +   scale_fill_tron()

text: Nan Xiao <@nanx.> | <https://nanx.>

title: The University of Chicago Color Scales ‚Äî scale_color_uchicago
code: library("ggplot2") data("diamonds")  p1 <- ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat >= 2.2),   aes(x = table, y = price, colour = cut) ) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +   geom_smooth(method = "loess", alpha = 0.1, size = 1, span = 1) +   theme_bw()  p2 <- ggplot(   subset(diamonds, carat > 2.2 & depth > 55 & depth < 70),   aes(x = depth, fill = cut) ) +   geom_histogram(colour = "black", binwidth = 1, position = "dodge") +   theme_bw()  p1 + scale_color_uchicago() #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_uchicago()   p1 + scale_color_uchicago(palette = "light") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_uchicago(palette = "light")   p1 + scale_color_uchicago(palette = "dark") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'  p2 + scale_fill_uchicago(palette = "dark")

title: ggsci 3.0.0
text: Use proper, three-component version number following Semantic Versioning. Reduce output figure size vignettes README.Rmd switching ragg PNG device using pngquant compression. simple solution interpolate color palettes data categories number colors discrete color scale. note using color scale consistently multiple ggplot2 plots setting global options (thanks, @DanChaltiel, #13). Replace size linewidth code examples ggplot2 >= 3.4.0. Replaced previous logo new hex sticker logo. Replaced previous CI/CD solutions GitHub Actions workflows. Fixed broken moved links function documentation vignettes. Removed LazyData field DESCRIPTION.
